title: 108_s2221
content: The Act titled "Umpqua National Forest Land Management Act of 2004" defines key terms and maps related to the management of Umpqua National Forest. It includes provisions for the sale or exchange of administrative sites within the forest. The Secretary has the authority to sell or exchange US rights in National Forest System land, including parcels like tract UMP-A and UMP-B in Roseburg, Oregon. The Umpqua Meridian in Douglas County, Oregon includes tract UMP-C, the Brown Street Residence Administrative Site in Glide, Oregon, covering approximately 2.35 acres. The Umpqua map and legal descriptions are available for public inspection until the land parcels are sold or exchanged. The Secretary has the authority to modify the map and descriptions for technical corrections or to facilitate conveyance. The Secretary may solicit offers for the sale or exchange of land under this Act, with consideration in the form of cash, land, or other considerations like construction of improvements. Offers may be rejected if deemed inadequate or not in the public interest. The Secretary may sell land at public or private sale, use a real estate broker, and conduct appraisals according to federal standards for land acquisitions. The Secretary may accept cash payments exceeding 25% of the land value in exchanges. Proceeds from land sales or exchanges are deposited in the Sisk Act fund for land acquisition and forest costs in Umpqua National Forest. The Secretary can accept cash payments exceeding 25% of land value in exchanges. Proceeds from land sales or exchanges are deposited in the Sisk Act fund for land acquisition and forest costs in Umpqua National Forest. Funds deposited under this Act are used for reimbursement of Secretary's costs, real estate broker commissions, and acquisition or rehabilitation of facilities in Umpqua National Forest. These funds cannot be paid to States or counties or considered as money received from units of the National Forest System for specific purposes. The Act of March 4, 1913 (16 U.S.C. 501) withdraws all land described in subsection (b) from public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws. The Secretary is required to revoke any public land orders that withdraw the land from appropriation under the public land laws. SEC. 4. WILDERNESS BOUNDARY ADJUSTMENT. Boundary Adjustment for the Rogue-Umpqua Divide wilderness as per the Oregon Wilderness Act of 1984 involves adjusting the boundary markers to new Angle Points 927B and 927C before reaching the original Angle Point 928. The Rogue-Umpqua Divide wilderness boundary is adjusted with new Angle Points 928A and 929, described as a high point on a ridge in Section 7. The Wilderness map is available for public inspection, and technical errors can be corrected by the Secretary. SEC. 5. Land acquired by the Secretary shall be managed according to the Weeks Act and other laws related to the National Forest System. Property management regulations do not apply to the sale or exchange of National Forest System land under this Act. SEC. 6. Appropriations are authorized as necessary to carry out this Act.
